Minum Kopi Teratur Bisa Bantu Kesehatan Sistem Pencernaan
06 Nov 2019, 22:45 by Praga Utama, Mitra Tarigan
TEMPO.CO, Jakarta - Manfaat kesehatan dari minum kopi semakin banyak ditemukan oleh para ahli. Sebelumnya, beberapa riset menyatakan minum kopi secara rutin dapat melawan lemak tidak sehat, mengurangi peradangan yang berkaitan dengan obesitas, dan melindungi otak hingga usia lanjut. Minum kopi juga dapat menjaga arteri tetap sehat dan lentur dengan mencegah penumpukan kalsium dan risiko penyumbatan. Selain itu, minum kopi membantu tubuh melawan diabetes dengan meningkatkan kontrol gula darah serta menjaga hati tetap sehat.
Kini para peneliti menemukan satu lagi alasan yang menguatkan kopi menjadi minuman kegemaran semua kalangan. Penelitian terbaru ini menyoroti mekanisme di balik efek kopi dengan melihat hubungan antara kopi dan kesehatan mikrobiota pada usus. Penelitian ini dilakukan di Pusat Inovasi dalam Kualitas, Efektivitas, dan Keselamatan, Pusat Medis Michael E. DeBakey VA, Baylor College of Medicine, di Houston, Texas, Amerika Serikat.
"Sudah banyak peneliti yang tahu bahwa mengkonsumsi kopi terbukti bermanfaat dalam melawan penyakit metabolisme," kata dokter Li Jiao, peneliti senior dalam riset ini, seperti dikutip Medical News Today, 30 Oktober lalu. "Dalam penelitian ini kami mengamati hubungan antara konsumsi kafein dan komposisi serta struktur mikrobiota dalam usus besar."
Untuk melakukannya, para ilmuwan meminta 34 peserta menjalani pemeriksaan kolonoskopi dan endoskopi untuk memastikan kesehatan usus mereka. Para peneliti lalu memeriksa 97 sampel biopsi dari berbagai segmen para peserta, mengekstraksi DNA mikroba, dan menganalisis urutan 16-rRNA.
Para peserta juga diminta mengisi kuesioner untuk mengevaluasi asupan kopi harian. Tim membagi asupan kopi menjadi konsumsi kopi tinggi, setidaknya 82,9 miligram per hari, dan konsumsi kopi rendah, yakni kurang dari 82,9 mg setiap hari.
Dari pemeriksaan itu terungkap bahwa para peserta yang rutin mengkonsumsi kafein dalam kategori tinggi memiliki tingkat bakteri Erysipelatoclostridium (E. ramosum) yang rendah. Ini adalah genus bakteri yang "berpotensi berbahaya". Li Jao, yang merupakan profesor gastroenterologi, mengatakan keberadaan bakteri E. ramosum dalam sistem pencernaan sebetulnya wajar. "Tapi, jika berlebihan, akan berbahaya."

Drinking Regular Coffee Can Help Your Digestive System's Health
06 Nov 2019, 22:45 by Praga Utama, Mitra Tarigan
TEMPO.CO, Jakarta - The health benefits of drinking coffee are increasingly being discovered by experts. Previously, several studies stated that drinking coffee regularly can fight unhealthy fats, reduce inflammation associated with obesity, and protect the brain to old age. Drinking coffee can also keep arteries healthy and supple by preventing calcium buildup and the risk of blockages. In addition, drinking coffee helps the body fight diabetes by increasing blood sugar control and maintaining a healthy heart.
Now the researchers found one more reason to strengthen coffee into a favorite drink of all circles. This latest research highlights the mechanism behind the effects of coffee by looking at the relationship between coffee and microbiota health in the intestine. This research was conducted at the Center for Innovation in Quality, Effectiveness, and Safety, the Michael E. DeBakey VA Medical Center, Baylor College of Medicine, in Houston, Texas, United States.
"Already many researchers know that consuming coffee has proven beneficial in fighting metabolic diseases," said doctor Li Jiao, senior researcher in this research, as quoted by Medical News Today, October 30 last. "In this study we looked at the relationship between caffeine consumption and the composition and structure of microbiota in the large intestine."
To do this, the scientists asked 34 participants to undergo colonoscopy and endoscopy examinations to ensure their intestinal health. The researchers then examined 97 biopsy samples from various segments of the participants, extracted microbial DNA, and analyzed the 16-rRNA sequence.
The participants were also asked to fill out a questionnaire to evaluate daily coffee intake. The team divides coffee intake into high coffee consumption, at least 82.9 milligrams per day, and low coffee consumption, which is less than 82.9 mg daily.
The examination revealed that participants who routinely consumed caffeine in the high category had low levels of Erysipelatoclostridium (E. ramosum) bacteria. This is a genus of "potentially dangerous" bacteria. Li Jao, who is a professor of gastroenterology, said the presence of E. ramosum in the digestive system is actually natural. "But, if it's excessive, it will be dangerous."
